ýýDistributive numerals are derived by reduplication of the rightmost root morpheme and suffixation according to the rule for cardinal numeralsýý. Distributive numerals can mean 'X units', 'X units each time', or 'in groups of X'. More on quantification on [page 239ýýý240].

-i is added when the reduplicate root ends with a consonant. If a root ends with a consonant, -i is attached to the end of the numeral (for example, lï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ab-lï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½abi 'three each'). In Tokitin, cardinal and distributive 'two' are the same because the root for 'two' in this subdialect is already reduplicated (k'ek'e). 'One each' is ce-ce, without class marker. [gadzhieva2007: 89] mentions use of an additional word: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿
[alekseyev2016: 3684] mentions that the pattern is either R-R-da or R-da-R-da. He also mentions that 'one each' is ce-ce-CM or ce-CM-ce-CM.

In simple numerals, only the numeral root is reduplicated. In numerals of hundreds the number marker is reduplicated (hab-beï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½i-beï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½en-da '300 each'), in numerals of tens the root morpheme is reduplicated (habiï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½-hab-ac'a '30 each'). ýýDistributive numerals are formed by adding the plural suffix -t'a to the cardinal stem, and distributive numerals can also be formed by reduplication. The reduplicated distributive numeral can optionally use the suffix -t'a. The meaning of distributive numerals used pronominally refers to a situation in which two or more individuals act on their own, i.e. individually and carry out one or more events with the same resultsýý. ýýIn complex numerals, only the last component is reduplicated or receives the distributive suffix -t'aýý (for example, oýýýc'on q'ýýýýene-t'a '12') [178]. ýýWhen the numeral ends in azar ýýýthousandýýý or milion ýýýmillionýýý, the component that precedes this numeral is reduplicated or receives the distributive suffix -t'a. The distributive numerals ýýýone thousandýýý and ýýýone millionýýý are formed either by attaching the distributive suffix -t'a directly to nouns azar ýýýthousandýýý and milion ýýýmillionýýý when the numeral hos ýýýoneýýý is omitted, the distributive suffix -t'a is added to the numeral hos ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿

ýýDistributive numerals are formed by adding the plural suffix -t'a to the cardinal stem, and distributive numerals can also be formed by reduplication. The reduplicated distributive numeral can optionally use the suffix -t'a. The meaning of distributive numerals used pronominally refers to a situation in which two or more individuals act on their own, i.e. individually and carry out one or more events with the same resultsýý. ýýIn complex numerals, only the last component is reduplicated or receives the distributive suffix -t'aýý (for example, oýýýc'on q'ýýýýene-t'a '12') [178]. ýýWhen the numeral ends in azar ýýýthousandýýý or milion ýýýmillionýýý, the component that precedes this numeral is reduplicated or receives the distributive suffix -t'a. The distributive numerals ýýýone thousandýýý and ýýýone millionýýý are formed either by attaching the distributive suffix -t'a directly to nouns azar ýýýthousandýýý and milion ýýýmillionýýý when the numeral hos ýýýoneýýý is omitted, the distributive suffix -t'a is added to the numeral hos ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿
There is also another reduplicated form of the distributive pronoun which is more emphatic and which is formed by adding the suffix -t'a to each reduplicant, e.g. hos-t'a-hos-t'a ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ýýThere are two different ways of forming distributive numerals in Hinuq. The first method is to add the ILOC-Essive suffix -ho to the direct stem of the numeralýý.

ýýThere are two different ways of forming distributive numerals in Hinuq. The second method is reduplication. Mostly the first syllable (CV) is reduplicated, but it also possible to reduplicate the first CVC or CVCV segment. The copy always preceded the base. Numerals with a root that is longer than CV can have several reduplicated forms that occur in free variation, e.g. ocýýýeno ýýýtenýýý has several variants of distributive numerals: o-oc'eno, ocýýý-oc'eno, and oc'e-oc'eno can be formed from the root oc'e-ýý.
ýýIn addition, both methods (i.e. reduplication and the use of the ILOC-Essive suffix) can be combined. In compound numerals, only the last numeral undergoes reduplication and/or takes case affixesýý. ýýCase suffixes are preferably added to the distributive numerals formed by means of reduplicationýý [407].

ýýDistributive numerals are formed by reduplication; in addition, a distributive (DISTR) suffix -cýýr can be added to 'ten' and 'twenty'. The distributive numeral for 'one' is sýý.sýýýý. It seems from the examples that the reduplication is often very fragmentary, one or two phonemes from the beginning of the word (for example, o-ýýoq'e-n 'four times'). [isakovkhalilov2001: 270] claims that -no is reduplicated as well: ýýýýýýýýýý-ýýýýýýýýýý 'five each'.

Either the root or just the first syllable is reduplicated. According to [alekseevetal1998: 281 (in the file)], ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï
The first root is the clean root, the second is amalgamated with -al the way it its amalgamated in the corresponding cardinal (if -al is present in the cardinal).

ýýDISTRIBUTIVE NUMERALS are formed by reduplication of cardinal numeralsýý.

ýýDistributive numerals are formed by reduplicating the root. Optionally the suffix -l(e) follows the reduplicated numeral. The suffix -l(e) seems to be the adverbializer. Note that with distributive numerals the modified noun bears overt plural markingýý.
Exception: 'first' is not derived by reduplication. The form for 'first' is written by hand in the source, it is something like ca-cleweb (but probably need correction).

ýýDistributive numerals are derived from the short form by full reduplication of the base numeral (partial reduplication is impossible even in long complex numerals). Distributive numerals can also serve as the base to form multiplicative and group numeralsýý.

comment: Distributives can be derived with reduplication of a cardinal root. They can be adverbialized with -ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½i. [mika
Distributives can be derived with reduplication of a collective numeral root. They can be adverbialized with -ï¿½ï

In reduplication, the stress is on the first instance of the numeral. In complex numerals, only the last component is reduplicated. However, '100', '1000' and larger numerals are not reduplicated; if they are the last component, the component before them is reduplicated. [alekseevetal1998: 353 (in the file)] gives examples both with reduplication of -d and without: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿
Only a part of the first component is reduplicated (the first syllable or the whole numeral [magometov1965: 165]). Unclear what happens in complex numerals.
Unlike [alekseevshixalieva2003: 54], [magometov1965] insists that distributive numerals always have suffix -ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿
Unlike [alekseevshixalieva2003: 54], [magometov1965] insists that distributive numerals always have suffix -di (-ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ýýPrefixalýý numerals (a.k.a. those who have frozen class markers in the beginning, apparently) derive distributives this way, without reduplication. Prefixal numbers are: '4', '6', '7', '8', '9', '10'. Class markers are usually omitted but there is evidence that sometimes they are present in this form. -na sometimes undergoes pharyngealization. [mukhin2020: 19] states that -na is the adverbial suffix. ýý[There is] evidence that the forms with -na are primaryýý.
It is said that it is possible to derive distributive numerals both with and without class markers (for most numerals). -na sometimes undergoes pharyngealization.
Numerals are repeated fully. No info on complex numerals.

ýýFor '1' to '3' the distributive is formed by suffixing a reduplicated and geminated copy of the initial consonant, to which the pronominal oblique endings are attached. From '4' on it is formed by simple doubling of the nominative cardinal (attributive form). Nominalized and attributive forms are identical in the nominative. Nominalized distributives were difficult to elicit and were often replaced by cardinals or attributive distributives. The nominalized form has case inflection but no gender; it is used in apposition to a pronoun or noun with which a verb or other agreeing word agreesýý. Unlike in Chechen, simple tens reduplicate fully (for example, qouztq'a qouztq'a 'sixty each') [214], no info on larger complex numerals.
